standard_metadata.standard_description: Know that straight lines are widely used to model relationships between two quantitative variables. For scatter plots that suggest a linear association, informally fit a straight line, and informally assess the model fit by judging the closeness of the data points to the line.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Eyeballing the line of best fit

question.content: **Which line fits the data graphed below?**

images.alt: A scatterplot on the x y axis where x and y scale by 1. Points rise diagonally in a narrow scatter between (1, 2) and (9, 9). A line labeled A increases diagonally extending from (0, 4) through (8, 10). A line labeled B increases diagonally extending from (0, 2) through (8, 8). A line labeled C increases diagonally extending from (0, 4) through (10, 5). All values are estimated.

options.content: None of the lines fit the data.

hints.content: A line of fit goes through the middle of the data points.
Line $\goldD{\text{B}}$ fits the data.

A line labeled C horizontally moves extending from (0, 5) through (10, 4). All values are estimated.

options.content: None of the lines fit the data.

hints.content: A line of fit goes through the middle of the data points.
Line $\maroonD{\text{A}}$ fits the data.
